name: NPR
text:
The established indie singer and songwriter Mark Kozelek, who frequently performs as Sun Kil Moon, has been accused of sexual misconduct by 3 women in a report published by Pitchfork.
https://t.co/VCjYblpZho

name: NPR
text: Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp has withdrawn a lawsuit he filed against Atlanta Mayor Keisha Lance Bottoms and the City Council over a mask requirement and other COVID-19-related safeguards.  https://t.co/hDN1jiC0OD

name: NPR
text:
"I heard it today that she doesn't meet the requirements. I have no idea if that's right," President Trump said of Sen. Kamala Harris, the presumptive Democratic vice-presidential nominee, who was born in Oakland, Calif.
https://t.co/VsoxJGUjsT

name: NPR
text:
Sue Gordon was in line to be acting Director of National Intelligence after Dan Coats quit last year. President Trump thought otherwise. 

Now, she recounts her time in his administration.
https://t.co/b0z6wqxpLI

name: NPR
text:
The director of the CDC is warning of the dual threat of the coronavirus and the flu this fall, urging Americans to wear a mask, social distance and get the flu vaccine.
https://t.co/R12Wv8DvHw

name: NPR
text:
The NCAA's president says there will be no championships this fall, with the possible exception of football, because not enough schools are participating due to cancellations and season postponements.
https://t.co/LUbu9Jksgp

name: NPR
text:
If you want to socialize with family or friends, can testing in advance keep everyone safe?  

We asked experts how diagnostic tests work and how to interpret the results. https://t.co/owkbU9gQ4I

name: NPR
text:
Giving kids deworming pills boosted their household income as adults by 13%, a new study finds. 

But there are significant caveats. For one, income boost was limited to men — even though women saw the biggest education gains.
https://t.co/R4m3jHJJtu

name: NPR
text:
The director of the CDC says if Americans don't follow public health guidance, the country could be facing "the worst fall, from a public health perspective, we've ever had."
https://t.co/hj2NTsMlcI

name: NPR
text: The state of play has changed since 2016. Governments and social media platforms have stronger countermeasures, leading Russia and China to rely on more official channels. But phony social media agitation has gotten more sophisticated and harder to spot. https://t.co/PMiYf8n2D7

name: NPR
text:
A growing number of school districts are offering solely remote learning. 

If you have school-aged kids, here are 20 questions that will help you figure out your best child care options for fall.
https://t.co/QJcq17fKTE

name: NPR
text:
Drug overdoses are spiking during the coronavirus pandemic, rising by roughly 18%, according to new data.

"The longer people had to isolate it was relapse, relapse, overdose, relapse, overdose," says a substance abuse counselor.
https://t.co/qOlefvcF60

name: NPR
text: For music therapist Julie Be, an album like her new "Trans & Nonbinary Kids Mix" would have meant a lot to them at a young age. "It definitely would have given me language that I did not have," they say. https://t.co/dwVtAHxkI2

name: NPR
text: If you're stressed out by battle royale shooter games like “Fortnite,” you may enjoy steering the jelly-bean-esque characters of “Fall Guys” around an array of goofy obstacle courses. https://t.co/avFtaxoagr

name: NPR
text:
Tribune Publishing is closing the physical offices of 5 newspapers permanently.

“We're still a newsroom, even if we don't have a home, but this is why we need local owners who care about journalism," the Orlando Sentinel Guild tweeted. https://t.co/SiRkyjYi1T

name: NPR
text: There are plenty of maps and forecasts when hurricanes spin up, but they're often confusing. The Short Wave podcast from @nprscience takes you inside the Cone of Uncertainty to explain how to think about storm tracks and strength. https://t.co/RhKOcFR6bR

name: NPR
text: Some federal prisons have a drug treatment program that allows for early release, but with the coronavirus sweeping through many facilities, the programs were put on hold. Now many inmates who expected to be home by now are stuck. @houpublicradio https://t.co/oD3DnHDcFd

name: NPR
text:
Democrat Joe Biden's lead has expanded to double-digits against President Trump in November, an NPR/PBS NewsHour/Marist poll finds. 

Meanwhile, though 71% of Americans now see the coronavirus as a real threat, 35% say they won't get vaccinated. https://t.co/iFtyUk5KOg

name: NPR
text:
Researchers are raising alarms about the meteoric rise of the baseless QAnon conspiracy theory — and its entry into politics. Georgia is set to become the first state to elect a supporter of the theory to Congress.
https://t.co/HzpKNEErM9

name: NPR
text:
Ammonium nitrate is a common chemical in farm fertilizers -- and terrorist bombs. When stored wrong it can cause huge blasts -- as seen in Beirut, Lebanon, and seven years ago in West, Texas. 

Experts say U.S. regulation of it is a flimsy, jumbled mess. https://t.co/QwLSzjLK8t

name: NPR
text: The U.S. is slowly dragging out of the sharpest economic contraction in modern history, though not as quickly as retailers would like. Sales were up 1.2% in July, led by electronics and appliances. Americans also cautiously went out to eat more. https://t.co/NA3QK5z4El

name: NPR
text: The big Democratic and Republican conventions are a political tradition dating back to the 1800s. But in the modern era, there's been growing criticism that they are outdated, expensive, multi-day infomercials. This year will shake up that format a bit. https://t.co/lwApmWhdY2
